risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Registered Social Worker & Masters of Social Work, Veterinary Social Work, Ontario Veterinary College and Health Sciences Centre, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, Canada

sect2.title: 15.1 Introduction
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians are skilled professionals who communicate with clients during some of the most challenging moments they face as caregivers to their companion animals. Technicians are well‐positioned to support clients as they navigate the grief associated with losing a companion animal. By offering compassionate communication and care, technicians help preserve and validate the bond between clients and their pets.

Approaching conversations about end‐of‐life (EOL) and pet loss can be intimidating. Veterinary teams can quickly be overwhelmed by the uncertainty of how clients may respond to grief, along with the discomfort that can arise when dealing with emotions such as sadness and guilt. For this reason, technicians need to understand where their role in providing grief support begins and ends. This chapter does not ask technicians to act as therapists or counselors. Instead, it aims to equip them with practical skills and strategies that align with their scope of practice. When technicians are well‐prepared with resources and know how to offer comfort in grief‐related conversations, they gain confidence in their roles and interactions. Engaging in compassionate interactions not only adds value and meaning to one’s work but also nurtures a sense of fulfillment and encourages self‐preservation.

InChapter 14, technicians gained insight into grief responses and reactions that people may experience after the loss of a companion animal. Building on the communication techniques and strategies discussed in Chapters 6 and 7, this chapter focuses on language, actions, and resources that can help technicians respond effectively to common grief reactions, as well as more specific grief scenarios. The author’s objective is to equip technicians with practical tools to navigate these difficult conversations, provide emotional support, walk with clients through the grieving process with empathy and understanding, and provide guidance around memorialization, all while maintaining professional boundaries.

sect2.title: 15.2 Language Sensitivity in Grief Support
sect2.para: When working with someone who has experienced a loss, it is often challenging to know what to say. It is common to worry about saying the “wrong thing” out of fear that it might make things worse for the person who is grieving. Therefore, what is the “right” language to use? Realistically, there are no magic words or phrases that can rid a person of their grief, and that is not the point of providing support. Grief is going to be present no matter what a technician says or does. Rather than “fixing” or “solving” a person’s grief, technicians can focus on using empathy to create a supportive space for clients to express themselves and share their experiences.

Technicians can use thoughtful language and open‐ended questions to meet an individual where they are in their grieving process. Empathy is actively working to understand a person’s unique perspective. Empathic language encourages people to share their feelings, thoughts, and needs without judgment.Table 15.1 includes practical examples of supportive language as well as language to avoid.

para.emphasis: Consider empathetic phrases, quotes, or metaphors that could help comfort and validate a person experiencing the loss of a pet.
Write down the ones that feel authentic for you, so you have them in mind when needed.

sect2.title: 15.3 Providing Grief Support and Memorialization
sect2.para: Memorialization refers to the ways an individual acknowledges and honors the life of the deceased. To further enhance compassionate care for clients grieving the loss of their pets, technicians may also facilitate memorialization. Death often prompts existential fear, dread, and anxiety for people who have lost a loved one. Memorialization can provide comfort in the face of this vast unknown. When those experiencing pet loss engage in meaningful memorialization, it helps to strengthen and preserve the bond they had with their petch0028-c15-bib-0001.

By offering practical support and resources such as aftercare options, memorial items, keepsakes, and follow‐up care, technicians can enhance the level of EOL care offered. These thoughtful gestures not only demonstrate empathy but also offer clients tangible ways to navigate their grief. This can even help to strengthen the rapport between the veterinary practice and its clientelech0028-c15-bib-0002. Be aware that not every client will need or want assistance with this. Let clients guide the level of support they require and do not force them to participate in something in which they are not interested.

sect2.title: 15.3.1 Aftercare Services
sect2.para: Memorialization often begins with the aftercare process. Clients want to know that their animals’ remains are handled with dignity and respect. Knowing the options for aftercare allows people to personalize the way their pet is kept and cherished. SeeChapter 13 for more information about aftercare. Having a technician to support and guide clients through the aftercare process helps alleviate some of the stress and uncertainty that follow the death of a pet. Clients are usually thankful that they have someone to help with arrangements, especially a trusted professional like a technician (Case Study 15.1).

Table 15.1
Grief language dos and don’ts.

entry.para:
Do: Acknowledge the Loss
Validate how significant this relationship was: “It is devastating to lose such a special companion.”
“Fluffy was such an important part of your family. You two had a deep connection.”

Don’t: Minimize the Loss
Statements that minimize the significance of the pet or the grief can be very hurtful: “Remember, you have another one at home that you can still love.”
“They don’t live as long as people. This is just part of having a companion animal.”

Do: Ask Open‐ended Questions
Prompt clients to share their feelings and needs by asking them: “What would be helpful for you through this process?”
“I’m here to listen. What are you feeling right now?”

Don’t: Make it About You
Avoid using a lot of “I” statements and making it about your personal experience with loss: “I know how you feel. I went through a painful loss with my pet.”
“I can’t imagine what you are going through, but I remember how I felt when I lost a pet.” There are times when a shared experience can be helpful for clients to hear. They might even ask you to tell them, but let clients guide this decision.

Do: Normalize Their Feelings
Clients sometimes feel their thoughts and reactions are irrational. Remind them that their feelings are a natural response to loss: “Your feelings are normal, and they are there for a reason. None of them are wrong or bad.”
“Fluffy was a huge part of your life and you loved him so deeply. It is natural to feel such profound grief. You have every right to feel this way.”

Don’t: Make Assumptions
Making assumptions about their feelings does not allow the individual to express what they really feel, and it may come off as dismissive: “You must be relieved he is not in pain and sick anymore. This was the best outcome for him.”
“You spent a long time caring for them while they were sick. It will be good to focus on other things now.”

Do: Provide Insights About the Grief Process
Offer perspective to help clients understand that grief is a journey with highs and lows, not a onetime event: “We would always rather the companions that we lost be here with us. In this way grief never ends, because we always love and miss them. Grief integrates into our lives and eventually, we find a way to live with the loss.”
Metaphors and quotes are powerful tools that help describe deep feelings and experiences that people can’t put into words. “Grief can feel like a roller coaster. It has highs and lows and sometimes loops backwards before moving forward again.”

Don’t: Impose Timelines on Grief
Grief has no set timeline, and implying it does might make clients feel they are not grieving correctly or that they should rush through their grief: “You will feel better in a few weeks and then you can get back to normal.”
“After a week you will feel ready to go back to work again.”

Do: Share Memories or Stories of the Pet
Share something genuine and heartfelt about the pet, and ask them to share as well: “Fluffy was always so well behaved ‐ one of our very best patients.”
“I would love to hear more about what Fluffy was like at home.”

Don’t: Offer Unsolicited Advice
Do not give advice on how the client should feel or what they should do: “You need to be strong now. That's what they would have wanted.”
“Maybe it will be helpful to get another one.”

Do: Allow for Silence
Sometimes words are not necessary. Recognize the power of silence. Just being present is enough in certain moments.

Don’t: Impose Personal Beliefs
Do not impose your own beliefs, attitudes, or values onto the individual: “Fluffy has crossed the rainbow bridge.”
“It was Fluffy’s time to go. He is in a better place now.”

sidebar.title: Case Study 15.1 Alex and Max
sidebar.para: Alex brought his 10‐year‐old Golden Retriever, Max, to his veterinary clinic after noticing sudden signs of distress. Max had been in good health, with only minor age‐related issues, so the sudden change was unexpected. Upon examination, the veterinarian shared with Alex that the most humane option for Max was to euthanize. Alex had not anticipated this outcome and was devastated but agreed that it was time to say goodbye.

After Max’s death by humane euthanasia, the technician and veterinarian offered Alex time alone with Max’s body to say his final goodbyes. The technician returned only when Alex signaled that he was ready, so he did not feel rushed or pressured. When the technician returned to sit down with Alex, he still seemed shaken by what happened.

Alex nodded, and the technician guided him through the available body care options. She explained the choices, including cremation and burial services. The technician was careful to explain each option in a clear and compassionate manner, reassuring Alex that there was no right or wrong choice, only what felt right for him.

After going through the options and pausing to ask questions, Alex still seemed unsure of what to do. He was mostly quiet, occasionally nodding his head and keeping his gaze down. The technician offered to pause the discussion for now. She assured Alex that they would keep Max safe at the practice while he decided what he wanted to do. She provided him with handouts about the local aftercare options and told him that once he was ready, he could call the practice, and she would help arrange the rest. She also made it clear that the clinic was there to support him beyond this moment, offering grief resources and suggesting that she follow up to check in with him during the week.

para.emphasis: In what ways did the technician communicate effectively and compassionately with Alex, considering his emotional state?
What signs did the technician observe that indicated Alex was overwhelmed?

sect2.para: Technicians should aim to discuss aftercare options before the pet’s death, ideally during EOL planning. However, there are times when this isn’t possible, and decisions must be made soon after the pet has died. This may add challenges to this conversation, as it can be overwhelming for clients to make decisions around aftercare while they are freshly grieving. If clients feel rushed or pressured, they may feel they didn’t get a chance to really think their options through. This can lead to regret around their decisions, which may negatively impact their memorialization and grief going forward.

sect2.title: 15.3.2 Memorial Activities and Keepsakes
sect2.para: Memorial activities and keepsakes create lasting memories that offer comfort and remembrance for years to come. The physical presence of pets in the lives of their caretakers is incredibly important. For many, pets occupied significant space in their home: their spot on the couch, the bed or crate where they slept, the spot where their food and water bowls were placed, the spaces where their leashes and toys were kept, and the physical comfort they provided (e.g. greeting them at the door after work, affection when feeling sad or overwhelmed, sleeping beside them). As a result, their absence is deeply felt. Many describe an emptiness or void in their homes after such a lossch0028-c15-bib-0001.

Memorial items will never replace the pet’s physical presence, but they can offer a tangible reminder of the special companion and the unbreakable bond that remains. Sometimes people will know exactly what they would like to do, whereas others may be unsure of where to start. The nice thing about memorialization is that there is no timeline on when it should be started or completed and no one way to do it (seePro Tip 15.1).

Memorialization is an important consideration for veterinary teams because there is often little guidance available for clients navigating this deeply personal process, and clients will likely ask about it. Many clients welcome suggestions on how to personalize their journey of honoring their beloved companion’s memory (seeTable 15.2, Case Study 15.2). Technicians can provide personalized keepsakes for their clients like fur clippings or nose/paw prints (see Figure 15.1). It is important that client permission is always obtained before any additional handling of the body or preparation of memorial items. Some clients may be upset that these activities occurred without their knowledge or consent. It is also very important that the requests and consent for these items be recorded in the medical record and ideally on the euthanasia (or hospice‐supported natural death) consent form.

Along with providing a list of suggestions for clients to memorialize their pets, technicians might also facilitate memorialization through the practice itself (seeFigure 15.2, Table 15.3). Clients often appreciate it when the practice offers a touching gesture to honor their pets. This also gives the veterinary staff an opportunity to engage in memorializing their patients, as many technicians develop strong bonds with clients and patients and may also be impacted by these losses. See Chapter 16 for memorialization geared towards families with children.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 15.1 Supporting Memorialization
sidebar.para: Flexibility, creativity, and open‐minded lack of judgment are essential when supporting clients through memorialization. It's important to reassure them that there are a variety of ways to honor their pet. What matters is that the process feels meaningful to them.

sidebar.title: Case Study 15.2 Caroline and Brutus
sidebar.para: Caroline is a single woman in her early 30s who has lost her first pet. Brutus was a gentle‐natured St. Bernard lost to osteoarthritis, which significantly decreased his quality of life. Caroline put so much love, care, and time into raising Brutus, and she wants to do the same when it comes to remembering him, but she is unsure where to start. Caroline speaks to a technician she knows well from her visits with Brutus and receives some suggestions.

The technician shares that Caroline’s memories with Brutus can be acknowledged in a way that feels personal and special to their bond. The technician asks if Caroline has any creative hobbies she enjoys, as perhaps there is a way to incorporate her memorialization into those activities. She also shares that the clinic website has a list of general suggestions for clients. Caroline takes these suggestions and gets creative with her memorialization. She orders a hand‐painted portrait of Brutus and a personalized necklace with his nose print, and she still has other ideas such as keeping a scrapbook or writing a story about him. She finds comfort in the fact that over time she can continue these activities.

sect2.para:
Table 15.3
Veterinary practice memorial ideas.

entry.para: Charitable donations: Consider making a small donation to a local animal shelter, charity, or clinic‐run charitable fund in the pet’s name and notify the client of this gesture.
Online memorials: Create an online memorial page and offer clients the opportunity to share a tribute to their pet on the clinic’s website or social media.
Memorial wall/book: Have a dedicated wall or book in the clinic and offer clients to bring in a photo of their pet to display (with client permission of course).
Social media: Post a tribute (with client permission) to the pet on the practice’s social media.

Pet memorialization event: Host a yearly remembrance event where clients and community members can gather to honor deceased pets. Or if there is an organization that hosts something like this already, provide this information to clients.

sect2.title: 15.3.3 Follow‐Up Care and Support
sect2.para: Follow‐up care is another important step in the memorialization process, as it extends the grief support provided by the practice beyond the client’s initial loss. By reaching out to clients after the loss of their companion animals, technicians demonstrate care and concern about the client’s well‐being and honor the memory of their pet. Technicians can effectively provide compassionate follow‐up care through phone calls, sympathy cards, and creating ceremony around picking up memorial items.

sect3.title: 15.3.3.1 Post‐Death Phone Call
sect3.para: A member of the EOL care team familiar with grief support should call clients within a week of their companion’s death. A call from the EOL care team demonstrates compassion for the loss and creates space to answer any lingering questions clients may have. This also provides time to remind them of resources for grief support that are available (Communication Corner 15.1). Keep this call within 20 minutes. It is important that it does not take longer than this, as it is meant to be a check‐in, not a counseling session.

para.emphasis: Start the call by introducing yourself, your role, and the reason for calling:

listitem.para: “Hello, Mrs. Smith. This is Leah, the veterinary technician at HappyPets Veterinary Clinic. I am reaching out to you today to offer our deepest condolences for the loss of Fluffy. This can be such a difficult time. How are you holding up?”

para.emphasis: Let the client respond and share. Listen empathically and let them lead the flow of the conversation. Once they have a chance to share, remind them of the resources available and ask if they have any other questions:

listitem.para: “I appreciate you sharing with me Mrs. Smith.” Before we end our conversation, I wanted to remind you of our pet loss resource list. If you feel it might be helpful, I am able to send it to you or you can find it on our webpage.”

para.emphasis: End the call and share that the practice valued caring for the pet:

listitem.para: “It was a privilege to be part of Fluffy’s care. We will miss him dearly. Take care and remember to be kind to yourself during this time.”

para.emphasis: At times, there will be clients who are eager to share many details, making it difficult to find a natural pause in the conversation. If you need to interrupt the client to end the call, it’s important to do so with sensitivity and care so that the client feels heard and respected.

listitem.para: “Mrs. Smith, I want to thank you for taking the time to speak with me today. I know this is a difficult time for you, and I appreciate you sharing your experience with me. I’ll let you go now, but please remember we’re here if you have questions or require resources. Take care.”
“Mrs. Smith, I’m so sorry to interrupt, but I do need to step away shortly. Please don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any questions. Take care and thank you for speaking with me today.”

para.emphasis: Ending a phone call with a grieving person can be hard, but it's important to remember that setting boundaries doesn't diminish the care and support provided. If you frequently find yourself on client calls lasting longer than 20 minutes, take a moment to reflect on why that might be happening.

sect3.title: 15.3.3.2 Sympathy Cards
sect3.para: The veterinary practice can express sympathy after the death of a patient by sending condolence letters or cards (seeTable 15.4, Communication Corner 15.2). These should be sent out as soon as possible after the death of the pet. One to three days after death is the window that the practice should aim for. Although digital cards are an option, paper sympathy cards sent via regular mail are generally very positively received (see Figure 15.3).

para.emphasis: Write uncomplicated and personal messages, a heartfelt, simple note written from the heart is so meaningful.

listitem.para: “It was truly an honor to care for Fluffy. Their gentle spirit and loving nature will always be remembered.”
“Fluffy looked at you with so much love in their eyes. Your bond was truly something special.”
“Your love and care for Fluffy was so evident. You gave them a beautiful life, and they knew how much they were loved.”

para.emphasis: Include specific memories or details shared during the time you got to know the animal.

listitem.para: “I’ll always remember how Fluffy greeted me at the reception desk with a wagging tail.”
“I’ll never forget Fluffy’s little dance at the treat jar – it always made me smile. They were such a joy to have around.”
“Fluffy had the funniest personality! I’ll always cherish the way they’d tilt their head when they were listening to me.”

para.emphasis: If struggling to write, choose a card with a meaningful pre‐written message.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 15.3 Picking Up Remains Suggestions

para.emphasis: Contact the owners by phone once the remains are ready for pickup. Speak calmly and gently, using the pet’s name.

listitem.para: “Hello, this is Jen from HappyPets Veterinary Practice. I am calling because Fluffy’s ashes have arrived at the clinic. They are here for you to pick up whenever it’s convenient for you.”

para.emphasis: Explain the options for pickup and ask when they would prefer to come by. Offer options that might make the process easier for them, such as a quieter time of day or even curbside pickup if they prefer more privacy.

listitem.para: “We can arrange for you to pick them up during a quieter time if that would make things easier for you. What time would work best?”

para.emphasis: Do not do the “burger and fries” handoff, that is, handing items over the counter. When the clients arrive, if possible, escort them to a quiet room or area where they can receive the remains without interruption. Greet the clients with a compassionate demeanor. Offer your condolences again and acknowledge their loss.

listitem.para: “Hi Mrs. Smith, we want to again offer our condolences for your loss. I know this is a hard moment, Fluffy was an incredible companion and member of the family. He is so deeply missed.”

para.emphasis: When handing over the remains, do so gently and with respect. If handing over ashes, offer the urn or container with both hands. Briefly explain any necessary details, such as what is inside the package (e.g. a lock of fur, a paw print).

listitem.para: “Here are Fluffy’s ashes. There is also a paw print as a keepsake, as you requested.”

para.emphasis: Do not just turn and walk away; allow a moment of silence or a pause for the clients to react. Be present and supportive during this time.

sect3.title: 15.3.3.3 Picking Up Remains
sect3.para: Picking up the remains of a deceased pet can be a very emotionally charged moment for pet parents. Technicians and their teams can establish a protocol for this situation that is sensitive to the importance of this event and supports the client in their grief (Communication Corner 15.3).

sect2.title: 15.4 Developing a Pet Loss Resource Guide
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians can take the initiative to create a Pet Loss Resource Guide for their practice. Having a resource guide readily available for grieving clients adds an extra layer of care from the veterinary team and demonstrates that they truly understand and empathize with this unique loss. This thoughtful gesture strengthens the relationship and trust between clients and the practice. By offering this resource, the clients can access appropriate support, and the veterinary practice can maintain the well‐being and professional scope of the technicians and staff members.

sect2.title: 15.4.1 Essential Components of a Pet Loss Resource Guide
sect2.para: A useful resource guide is composed of local and national options that clients can easily access online, in‐person, or by phone. Thankfully, many resources can be provided virtually now, which removes geographic barriers. Technicians should verify that the services are legitimate and trustworthy. A well‐rounded resource guide should include the following:

listitem.para: Therapists/counselors: Therapists and counselors collaborate with individuals on specific issues like grief for a limited amount of time or provide long‐term support focusing on self‐perception, thoughts, behaviors, and underlying patterns. As this list is related to pet loss, it is important to make sure the professionals included are comfortable discussing grief related to pet loss.

Veterinary social workers: A veterinary social worker is a mental health professional whose specialty is supporting the human–animal bond (HAB). They might work in veterinary hospitals or animal shelters and provide counseling and EOL support to pet parents. See Chapter 17 for more info on veterinary social workers.

Pet loss support groups: Support groups are gatherings of individuals facing similar issues such as pet loss. They provide a sense of community and shared experience, which can reduce feelings of isolation and increase social support. Have a mix of in‐person and virtual options listed.

Hotlines: Hotlines are dedicated telephone services designed to provide immediate support, counseling, and resources to individuals who are experiencing specific issues. Technicians can include grief hotlines, community health hotlines; and crisis/distress hotlines. Include both national and local options where possible.
Podcasts/books/videos/websites: Including educational media content around pet loss is a helpful option for clients to explore.

sect2.para: The Pet Loss Resource Guide needs to be kept current (seePro Tip 15.2). Veterinary teams can set a reminder to review and update it every six months to ensure the resources listed are dependable and up to date. Have this list openly displayed and easily accessible, such as on the practice website or visible in comfort/exam rooms and waiting areas. Staff should also give a physical copy of this list to clients after euthanasia or EOL planning appointments. A Pet Loss Resource Guide Template can be found at the end of this chapter (15A).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 15.2 Sourcing Pet Loss Resources
sidebar.para: Technicians can source pet loss resource information by tapping into local veterinary networks and professional associations to find vetted therapists, social workers, and support groups specializing in pet loss.

sect2.para: The use of a Pet Loss Resource Guide is a helpful way to set boundaries for the veterinary practice staff, as clients can be referred to specialized care when conversations around grief start to go beyond the scope of the veterinary team’s knowledge and abilities. Remember that it is not a technician’s role (or anyone’s role) to convince clients to use resources. Even if a technician thinks that a client may need mental health support, that is a client’s choice to make for themselves.

sect2.title: 15.5 Addressing Specific Grief Responses
sect2.para: Certain grief responses pose a more specific set of challenges and a higher level of communication skills. The following section aims to provide specific examples of strategies technicians may use in the face of various grief responses.

sect2.title: 15.5.1 Anticipatory Grief: Preparing Caregivers
sect2.para: As discussed inChapter 14, grief can begin well before a companion animal’s death. Anticipatory grief is a familiar experience for many caregivers but is often unacknowledged by people’s social support or by the person themselves ch0028-c15-bib-0003. Technicians working with clients may notice the emotional impact of anticipatory grief. For example, anxiety and fear are common as clients brace themselves for the inevitable loss of their pets. This may present as guilt related to spending time with their pets and the decisions being made about their care as well as caregiver burden. The responsibility of decision‐making and caregiving during this time can be overwhelming for clients, leading to emotional and physical exhaustion ch0028-c15-bib-0003. Remember, technicians are not responsible for relieving clients of their grief. Technicians can instead offer words of compassion and resources to those who are struggling (Communication Corner 15.4).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 15.4 Responding to Anticipatory Grief

emphasis.emphasis: “I’m terrified of what life will be like without Fluffy. I don’t know how I’m going to cope when he’s gone.”

listitem.para: “It’s completely natural to feel that way. Fluffy has been such an important part of your life, and it’s hard to imagine what life would be like without him. It’s okay to feel scared and uncertain about the future. We’re here to support you through this process, and there are resources available to help you cope, both now and after.”

emphasis.emphasis: “Every time I look at him, I feel this sinking feeling in my stomach, knowing that I’ll have to say goodbye soon.”

listitem.para: “It’s so tough to carry that kind of weight every day. It’s clear how much you love him, and that bond is what makes this so hard. Try to focus on the special moments you still have with him and know that your feelings are valid. Fluffy is living in the present. He knows that he is with you and loved. Try to be present with him in those moments.”

emphasis.emphasis: “I’m so scared of making the wrong decision. What if I choose to let him go too soon?”

listitem.para: “Making this kind of decision is incredibly difficult, and it’s understandable to have these fears. Remember that you’re making these choices out of love and care for Fluffy. We’re here to help guide you and provide the information you need to make the best decision for him. You won’t be doing this alone. We’re here to support you every step of the way.”

emphasis.emphasis: I feel so guilty that I couldn’t spend more time with Fluffy when he was healthy. Now I’m just trying to make up for it.”

listitem.para: “It’s understandable to feel that way, but it’s important to remember that you’ve always done your best for Fluffy. Life can be busy and sometimes it’s hard to find the time we wish we had. What matters now is the love and care you’re giving him at this moment. He knows how much you love him, and that’s what he feels most.”

emphasis.emphasis: “I keep questioning if I’m doing enough for him. Should I have tried harder to find another treatment option?”

listitem.para: “It’s natural to second‐guess yourself when you care so much about someone. It’s clear how much you love Fluffy and how dedicated you’ve been to his well‐being. Sometimes, despite all our efforts, there are limits to what can be done. It is helpful to focus on the intention behind decisions not the outcomes.”

emphasis.emphasis: “I’m worried that I’m being selfish in wanting to keep him around longer, even though I know he is sick and uncomfortable.”

listitem.para: “That’s a difficult feeling to have, and it’s completely normal to feel conflicted. It’s because you love him so much that you want to keep him close. It’s not selfish to want more time with him; it’s a sign of the deep bond you share. What’s important is balancing that love with what’s best for Fluffy’s quality of life, and we’re here to help you navigate that balance.”

emphasis.emphasis: “It’s exhausting trying to keep up with all of Fluffy’s medications and care routines. I’m just so tired all the time.”

listitem.para: “It’s completely understandable to feel exhausted, caring for Fluffy is a full‐time job, and it can be physically and emotionally draining. It’s okay to feel tired and overwhelmed. Please remember to take care of yourself too. Is there something that we can help with or revisit to help lighten the load?”

emphasis.emphasis: “I feel like I’m constantly on edge, worrying about his every little movement and whether he is comfortable.”

listitem.para: “That constant worry is something many caregivers experience. It’s a sign of how deeply you care for Fluffy, but it’s also important to recognize that you’re doing everything you can to keep him comfortable. We can help you monitor his comfort and address any concerns you have. You're not in this alone.”

emphasis.emphasis: “I’m overwhelmed by all the decisions I have to make. I feel like no matter what I do, it’s never enough. I feel like I’m failing him.”

listitem.para: “The weight of making these decisions can be incredibly overwhelming, and it’s so common to feel like you’re not doing enough‐even when you’re doing your best. We’re here to support you and help you navigate through these decisions, so you don’t have to carry this alone.”

sect2.title: 15.5.2 Integrating Cultural Sensitivity in Grief Support
sect2.para: InChapter 14, the impact of culture and spirituality on the grief experience was discussed. Cultural and spiritual sensitivity in EOL care does not require specific knowledge of different cultures or spiritual traditions. A technician’s role in these situations is to simply encourage clients to express their needs, beliefs, and wishes in relation to their pet’s EOL journey and their memorialization and mourning. The technician can then offer support as families prepare and carry out those wishes. This section and 15.5.3. will more specifically examine how memorial activities and rituals are important in multiple cultures or spiritual beliefs and their role in pet loss.

In Western culture, rituals in memorializing are well‐established for people but not for pet loss. For example, consider Catholic traditions for human loss: a funeral service typically follows a predetermined structure, starting with a religious service, followed by a viewing, a procession to the cemetery for burial, and concluding with socialization. Even dress codes are established and widely understood. These traditions around memorializing the deceased often establish a “right to grieve”ch0028-c15-bib-0004. In Catholicism, for instance, the bereaved may find comfort in the belief that the deceased has gone to heaven and will reunite with loved ones in the afterlife, and the Catholic ceremony reaffirms this belief. Case Study 15.3
provides an example of a technician supporting the needs, beliefs, and values of a Sikh family in their grief. When formal or established activities such as this are lacking for pet loss, it can negatively affect a person’s grief ch0028-c15-bib-0005.

sidebar.title: Case Study 15.3 Alina and Daisy
sidebar.para: Alina is a young adult living with her parents and their beloved Pomeranian Daisy in their family home. At 16 years old, Daisy’s health has been declining. After a particularly difficult week where Daisy’s quality of life noticeably worsened, Alina and her family make the hard decision to euthanize her.

Before taking Daisy to her final appointment, Alina and her parents gather in their home to say prayers and sing hymns, in a modification of their Sikh tradition usually observed when a human family member passes away. This ritual brings them comfort, as they honor Daisy as a beloved member of the family.

After Daisy’s euthanasia, Alina struggles with the decision about her aftercare. She knows that both she and her parents want Daisy to be cremated, but Alina feels conflicted. On one hand, she wants to be present when the cremation service prepares Daisy’s body, believing that Daisy, as a member of their family, deserves the same respect and rituals as any other loved one. On the other hand, she and her parents are uneasy at the thought of seeing Daisy’s body in that state. They want to remember Daisy as she was in life, not as she is now. Alina worries that if she doesn’t witness the preparation, she might later feel guilty.

Seeking guidance, Alina shares her concerns with the technician at the veterinary practice. The technician listens empathically and suggests that Alina first contact the crematory to inquire about the possibility of viewing Daisy’s body preparation and what that experience might entail. The technician emphasizes that gathering information could be a helpful first step, allowing the family to make a more informed decision. She also suggests that Alina consider consulting a spiritual advisor or trusted person within their faith who might offer additional insight.

Alina feels reassured after speaking with the technician. Initially overwhelmed by the decision, she agrees that it’s worth exploring the options before making a final choice. A few days later, Alina called the technician to follow up. She expresses her gratitude for the suggestions and shares that the crematory was willing to accommodate viewing. After further discussion with her parents, they decide against the viewing. They feel more at peace with their decision, preferring to remember Daisy as she was during her life. They are comforted by the prayers they offered before the euthanasia and plan to scatter Daisy’s ashes together in her favorite spot, another Sikh tradition they can include.

para.emphasis: In what way did the technician practice cultural sensitivity during this scenario?
Why do you think Alina turned to the technician for guidance on this personal matter?

sect2.title: 15.5.3 Integrating Spiritual Sensitivity in Grief Support
sect2.para: There are times when grieving clients may ask technicians questions about spirituality and the afterlife concerning their deceased pets. Technicians should approach these conversations with sensitivity, avoiding the disclosure of their personal beliefs. Often, clients are not seeking concrete answers but rather comfort and reassurance.Communication Corner 15.5 gives examples of technicians responding to caregiver questions relating to spirituality. In these responses, the technician is putting the question back to the client. This can help the technician guide their response in a way that acknowledges the clients’ beliefs around the afterlife without imposing a particular opinion or belief system. As a general rule when answering questions of this nature, avoid assuming a person’s set of beliefs. Instead, ask open‐ended questions and listen with compassion. Technicians can also suggest that clients connect with a spiritual advisor of their faith.

sect2.title: 15.5.4 Supporting Grieving Pet Owners with Suicidal Ideation
sect2.para: There are those instances where an individual is so overwhelmed by their grief that they experience suicidal ideations or intent. Suicidal ideation refers to thoughts of ending one’s own life, while suicidal intent involves concrete plans or preparations to carry out suicidal acts. Suicidality as a grief response can happen for different reasons. As mentioned inChapter 14, Prolonged Grief Disorder (PGD) can influence this response, but there are also factors like preexisting health conditions such as depression and anxiety disorders or substance abuse issues that might contribute to suicidal thoughts and actions [ch0028-c15-bib-0006, ch0028-c15-bib-0007]. Grief can be so deeply painful, sometimes the thought of living without a beloved companion animal can feel devastating and unbearable. People who have struggled with suicidal ideations or intent in the past will sometimes share that it was their companion who gave them the purpose to continue living.

Veterinary technicians might hear those affected by pet loss express that they wish they could have been “taken” instead or that they could be with that pet in death. Hearing these comments, although alarming, does not necessarily indicate that someone is going to harm themselves, but they should be taken seriously. People experiencing suicidal ideation may express feelings of hopelessness, withdraw from social life, neglect their self‐care and hygiene, give away personal belongings, or even explicitly mention suicide ch0028-c15-bib-0008. When a bereaved person is exhibiting these signs, symptoms, and behaviors, it warrants compassionate inquiry and referral to mental health professionals. It is everyone’s responsibility to respond to suicidality.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 15.5 Responding to Questions about Spirituality

emphasis.emphasis: “Where do you think Fluffy is now?”

listitem.para: “That is a good question. It is something many people wonder about. I am curious to know what you believe will happen.”

emphasis.emphasis: “I want a sign that they are still with me, do you think I will get one?”

listitem.para: “There are many ways that people feel connected to their pets, even after they have passed. It is normal to hope for a sign that helps confirm they are still with you. What do you think would bring you comfort or reassurance?”

emphasis.emphasis: “I am questioning my faith. How could God take away Fluffy? He was so good.”

listitem.para: “Losing a companion like Fluffy, who brought so much joy and love, is hard to make sense of. It's okay to feel confused, or even to question your faith. Grief can make us wonder why these things happen, and there's no easy answer. Have you considered speaking with another trusted person of your faith?”

sect2.para: Responding to a client who discloses suicidal thoughts can be incredibly stressful for a technician, yet it also presents an opportunity to provide compassionate care. Veterinary practice staff should strongly consider engaging in crisis and suicide intervention training. Courses such as Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) and Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) provide people with the skills and confidence needed to respond effectively to such sensitive situations, ensuring that they fulfill their duty of care in keeping clients safe. With the right training, technicians can approach these situations with greater confidence and preparedness. Along with training for these scenarios, it is also useful for veterinary practices to have a guideline or protocol for how the team can respond to suicidality. A full sample template for suicide response guidelines is located at the end of the chapter (15B). SeeCommunication Corner 15.6 for sample dialogue to use in these challenging situations.

listitem.para: Veterinary technicians equipped with a clear understanding of their role in grief support can confidently and empathically interact with grieving individuals.
Technicians facilitate memorialization through the provision of practical resources like aftercare options, memorial items, keepsakes, and follow‐up care.
Veterinary technicians may be instrumental in the creation of Pet Loss Resource Guides for use in their practice.
Preparing for EOL interactions by considering communication strategies for caregivers experiencing different grief responses will build the technician’s confidence.
Compassionate care, empathic language, and provision of resources allow technicians to support grieving clients as they navigate pet loss while maintaining professional boundaries.
15.1 Alex and Max
15.2 Caroline and Brutus
15.3 Alina and Daisy

The technician communicated effectively by being compassionate, patient, and clear. She acknowledged Alex’s emotions, reassured him there was no right or wrong choice, and explained the options in a gentle, step‐by‐step manner. She allowed Alex time to process the information, paused to ensure understanding, and offered to revisit the discussion later, ensuring he didn’t feel pressured to decide immediately. Instead of assuming what would be helpful, the technician asked the client first.

The technician observed Alex being mostly quiet, keeping his gaze down, nodding occasionally, and appearing unsure during the discussion. These behaviors indicated that he was struggling to process the situation and felt overwhelmed by the decisions he needed to make. The context also helped the technician with their observations – this client did not anticipate euthanizing their dog that day.

Caroline may have asked for support because this was her first experience losing a pet, and she was unsure of how to start the process of memorializing him. She wanted to ensure that she honored Brutus in a meaningful way that reflected their bond and trusted the technician from previous interactions to express this to them.
The technician’s suggestions were helpful because they encouraged Caroline to make the process personal and reflective of her relationship with Brutus.

The technician listened empathically and without judgment to Alina’s questions and concerns. They validated Alina’s wishes to incorporate Sikh traditions into aftercare/memorialization and demonstrated respect towards Alina’s cultural values and spiritual practices. The technician also offered practical guidance by suggesting Alina contact the cremation service to gather information about the process, empowering her to make an informed decision aligned with her cultural beliefs and comfort level.

The technician is a trusted professional in a role associated with compassionate care and support during grief related to pet loss, and Alina may have felt the technician could provide unbiased, nonjudgmental guidance on aftercare options for Daisy. The technician’s empathic demeanor created a safe environment for Alina to express her conflicted feelings.

sect2.title: 15.B Suicide Response Guidelines for Veterinary Practices

sidebar.para: Providing compassionate support to clients experiencing distress is part of the veterinary practice’s responsibility. These guidelines will help you recognize and respond appropriately to signs of suicidality among clients.
Be attentive to clients who exhibit the following:
Any expressions of hopelessness and despair
Anger and mood changes.
Withdrawal from communication or unresponsiveness.
Reckless or self‐destructive actions.
Giving away personal belongings.
Verbalizing feelings of hopelessness, helplessness, feeling trapped, or intense anger.

Safety Precaution: If concerned about a client’s safety, ensure that examination rooms are free of items that could be used for self‐harm (e.g. needles, scissors, medications), especially if the client is left alone.
If warning signs are present, engage the client with empathy and directness. It is important to get a yes or no answer.
Note: Asking directly about suicidal thoughts does not increase the risk; it shows care and allows for necessary support.
Stay with the client and express empathy,
Ask if there is a trusted friend or family member who can be contacted to provide support.
Inquire about existing professional support:
Offer to call a suicide prevention hotline together:
If the client refuses, make the call yourself to seek guidance on the next steps.
Arrange for a safe way for the client to get home or to a healthcare facility, preferably accompanied by someone they trust.
Document the interaction according to your practice’s policies.
Schedule a follow‐up call to check on the client’s well‐being.

para.emphasis: “I understand that this is an incredibly hard time for you. We're here to support you through this process.”

sidebar.para: Offer information about grief counseling services and support groups specializing in pet loss.
Provide contact information for mental health support services in case their feelings intensify:
Schedule a follow‐up call to check in on their coping and offer additional support as needed.
Before the client leaves, ensure they have access to helpful resources:
List of local and online pet loss support groups.
Contact information for grief counselors specializing in pet bereavement.
National and local crisis hotline numbers.
Information on accessing mental health services.
Emergency Action: If you believe the client is in immediate danger and refuses help, contact emergency services to request a wellness check.
Your compassionate intervention can make a significant difference in a client’s life during times of distress. Always prioritize safety, empathy, and appropriate professional support.
